div.p: From Clara Wehl to Louise Matthiessen
RB MSS M100b, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
I cannot tell you how sorry I am about you being laid up with your poor back so often; do you keep on taking lemon water? The Dr told Will he could cure himself by taking as much lemon water as he could take, & Wills back has been much better ever since. I would consult him about you, but if your complaint was the same of course the same remedy would do for you & if it is not the same, the Dr could hardly know without seeing you. I do wish I was well off & could keep you a servant you poor girl; I cannot even get a few Xmas presents. I am sure rest would do much for you. Could you & May not also go to Laura
SA?
? I do not like you being in B.H.
Broken Hill, NSW?
at all, the air must be pregnated with lead, though it may not be as bad as it used to be, & that never gets out of the system again. I am glad for Jack to get away a little while, he must need a little change. I wish you a happy Xmas dear, you & Jack & the Children. I will not say a merry one for I know you cannot quite be that; but my dear child we will at least be glad & thankful for those blessings still ours. May the New Year be a happy & prosperous one for you & us! Will went to Gladstone
SA?
on business, you know he is dealing now & is often from home; it was impossible to go & see you, much as he would have liked it, he had other appointments to meet, & was only one day in Adelaide & then so tired that he did not even see Meta, he would have had to go late in the day, as she was on night duty & therefor slept in daytime, now she is on day duty again. To day is the dear Childs birthday, 25 years old, how the time has gone, fancy my baby that age! I am glad she is very happy in her vocation, every one tells me how bright & happy she looks. I would like to see her in her Nurses Uniform. - Thank you for sending Ett my letter, it was thoughtful of you; yes I get a good deal of writing, but sometimes keep you all waiting longer then I like. I had letters from Ferd & Art on 12th. Ferd was doing very well, but it is a hard rough life for him & the heat so great; he wrote by a rushlight in a draughty hut, because his spare candles had melted; still he likes his present employment better then the life on that Station; & he is likely to make a little money when once his teams are paid for. Artie was trying to get a team & cart at Marble Bar,
WA.
to do the same thing, & if he does not succeed will join Ferdie. They are 60 miles apart. Arts back had been bad too, for that reason he cannot do hard work. I told him about Lemons, but he can not get them there. - The mine in which he was employed closed for a time. It will be nice for the boys to be together at "Lalla Rookh". Ferds address is still Port Hedland.
WA.
I miss you all this time of year, Marie & I are going to Ehren
‘Ehrenbreitstein’, near Millicent, the former home of Clara and Eduard Wehl?
for Xmas dinner, & Ted if he can get away; Boxing Day we go from there to Lake Bonney
SA.
to join Thyne’s picnic party. Berta
Musterdes inserted in another hand. was on her way home but stayed a few days with friends at the Mount
Mount Gambier, SA.
& while out driving they had an upset; she was hurt, but they think not seriously, but Annie did not feel easy about her & is gone to her by to days train. The Dr & Mr Capper came & had a few games of whist with us, we all enjoyed it, they were such close games; they had to leave early as the Dr always sees Mr Cammeron about 9 p.m. I think I told you Mr J. C. of Wattle Range was operated for hydatids, he is now nearly well. Our Hospital has been nearly full of patients since it was opened, it saves the Dr many long rides in the Country; he used to be nearly worked to death befor. Willie Stuckey has been under his treatment with absece on the jaw, he is better & returns with his wife to Petersburg in a week, she is a very nice sensible woman. Mr O'Hara & his mother have left for good. Mrs Forbes asked me to give you her love; she always inquires after you. Did you know Fritzie
Overhue inserted in another hand .
& Jack H
Name extended to Harris in another hand .
have joined the volunteers in Perth? they like it very much. Jack sent me his photo taken in his uniform, he looks very nice. Bertha can be proud of her children. I had a nice little holiday of 5 days at the Mount with Inglebys; it was so nice & quiet there, & so funny to be in Uncle Doughty's
Bertha Muller’s husband, George Doughty.
old house; it is so different now, a new suit of rooms added & a hall & passage; only their sitting room is left as it was. People who had it before cut down all those beautiful laurels & other big plants; the I's have now planted different other trees in their places, but the apricot tree is still on the house & bearing well & the little yellow banksia rose on the verandah. As I wanted to benefit by the visit I did not tire myself by calling on peeple, but Mrs I. gave me an afternoon & dear Mrs Tucker came; we had a good old talk & she looked so nice & so well. Mrs Glen & Emmy, Mrs Burton & Margie French also came, it was nice to see them all again. Mrs Ingleby drove me to see Mrs Needham, the dear old lady was very bright & so glad to see me, but is now very feeble, she is 92. Two of her grandsons from the West were there which was a great pleasure to her; they were from home when I called. Ellie will be with her now & May gone back to her father. We called also at Caldwells but both were from home. Then I saw Mr Webb
Not further identified.
in his shop, his hair is perfectly white; his wife had Influenza so I did not go to see her. Pelham Burten came back from Africa & has returned there. Katie went with her husband to Northern Territory; I think he had to go for a year relieving another Officer; she tells her mother it is a horrible place & they are being frizzled. Clara will not be with us this Xmas, she is going for a trip to Tasmania with Carrie Jacob, they will spend Xmas week in Melbourne with friends. C. said she might see the Potters,
Uncle's executor inserted in another hand. she is so disgusted with them I do not think she will visit them. She & Mrs Chapman may come to the S. E.
i.e. the South-East of SA.
later in the summer. Tell the dear Children I would like nothing better then to see them again, we will hope the time not to far when we will meet again. Marie sends her love & will write after the holidays & tell you of our doings. Good by now dear Lu, make yourself as happy as you can, give my love to Jack & Believe me ever lovingly thinking of you.
